skill.description: Low-level plotting library for full customization. Use when you need fine-grained control over every plot element, creating novel plot types, or integrating with specific scientific workflows. Export to PNG/PDF/SVG for publication. For quick statistical plots use seaborn; for interactive plots use plotly; for publication-ready multi-panel figures with journal styling, use scientific-visualization.

content.value_statement: Matplotlib provides complete control over every visual element for creating publication-quality figures. Master both pyplot and object-oriented interfaces to build any chart type from simple line plots to complex multi-panel scientific visualizations.
actual_capabilities: Generate any plot type: line, scatter, bar, histogram, heatmap, contour, 3D
Export figures in PNG, PDF, SVG formats with publication-ready DPI settings
Create multi-panel layouts using subplots, GridSpec, or mosaic arrangements
Customize every visual element: colors, fonts, labels, legends, annotations
Apply style sheets and rcParams for consistent branding across plots
limitations: Static plots only - no built-in interactivity like Plotly
Requires Python environment with matplotlib installed
Steep learning curve for complex customizations
Not suitable for real-time or streaming data visualization

best_practices: Always use the object-oriented interface (fig, ax = plt.subplots()) for better control and maintainability
Set figure size and DPI appropriately for your output medium (300 DPI for print, 150 DPI for web)
Use constrained_layout=True or tight_layout() to prevent overlapping elements
anti_patterns: Avoid using the pyplot state machine interface for complex figures - it leads to confusing code
Do not use rainbow/jet colormaps - they are not perceptually uniform and can misrepresent data
Never save figures without bbox_inches='tight' - it leaves unnecessary whitespace

faq.question: What is the difference between pyplot and object-oriented interfaces?
faq.answer: Pyplot is MATLAB-style with implicit state, while OO interface gives explicit control. Use OO for production code.

faq.question: How do I save high-quality figures for publications?
faq.answer: Use plt.savefig('figure.png', dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight') for print quality. Use PDF/SVG for vector graphics.

faq.question: Why are my subplot labels overlapping?
faq.answer: Add constrained_layout=True when creating subplots or call fig.tight_layout() before saving.

faq.question: Which colormap should I use?
faq.answer: Use viridis/plasma for sequential data, coolwarm for diverging data, and tab10 for categorical data.

faq.question: How do I create a colorblind-friendly plot?
faq.answer: Use colormaps like viridis or cividis, and add patterns or hatching to bars in addition to colors.

faq.question: Can I use matplotlib in Jupyter notebooks?
faq.answer: Yes, use %matplotlib inline for static plots or %matplotlib widget for interactive plots in Jupyter.
